Oxarc, Inc.
2513 3rd Avenue
Lewiston, Idaho 83501

Oxarc, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the company's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the receipt of containers, storage, and employee training associated with the covered process at this facility. It is policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

Under the Accidental Release Prevention Program, responsibility for the proper handling and storage of toxic gases stored at the OXARC - Lewiston, Idaho (Lewiston) facility is overseen by the EHS Manager and by the EHS Coordinator. Additionally, OXARC, Inc. senior management have responsibility to ensure facility managers and compliance personnel keep the program up-to-date and that all reports and findings are taken care of in a timely manner.

The Regulated Substances Handled
The facility is accessible to about twenty (20) authorized employees and is secured during non-operational hours. There is one (1) substance at this facility above the threshold quantity. Chlorine is stored and handled at the facility in compressed gas containers. The estimated maximum amount of chlorine on hand is approximately 6,000 pounds in 2,000-pound and 150-pound containers. There are no filling processes performed at this facility.

General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
This facility has taken all of the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at this facility. 

Process Safety Information 
OXARC, Inc. maintains safety information that describes the chemical hazards, handling, and storage of the regulated substance at this facility. All affected personnel are trained on hazmat handling.

Process Ha

zard Analysis
This facility conducts reviews to ensure that hazards associated with the handling and storage of cylinders are identified and controlled efficiently. Any findings related the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA review was performed on 1/27/2023.

Operating Procedures
For the purpose of safely handling and storage of chlorine containers, OXARC, Inc. has written procedures that address the loading, unloading, and safe handling of cylinders. These procedures are contained in the Safe Work Practice, Safe Handling of Cylinders Policy. Oxarc follows guidance set forth by the Compressed Gas Association (CGA) in determining the safe operating conditions and required inspections and tests necessary to maintain the equipment in the Chlorine Storage Process.

Training
OXARC, Inc. has a comprehensive program in place to ensure employees who are responsible for the handling of hazardous substances are competent in the procedures. Refresher training is provided on an ongoing basis.

Mechanical Integrity
OXARC, Inc. takes great care in ensuring that the structural integrity of its equipment is maintained throughout the handling and storage of containers and any equipment associated with the process.

Management of Change
The most recent review/revision of procedures was performed 2/24/2023. Employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in the operating procedures are promptly made aware of and trained in these changes.

Compliance Audits
A compliance audit has not been completed at the facility. Oxarc will complete a compliance audit within three (3) years of this initial RMP Registration.

Incident Investigation
OXARC, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could result in an unintentional release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports ar

e retained for a minimum of 5 years. There has not been an incident at this facility.

Employee Participation 
OXARC, Inc. believes that safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. OXARC employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. OXARC employees are given the opportunity to voice any concerns during monthly safety meetings as well as through an open-door policy. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from any hazard analyses.

Contractors
On occasion, OXARC, Inc. hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety of the contractor is carried out. OXARC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release occur. However, contractors are not involved with any process relating to the regulated chemicals.

Five-Year Accident History
There is no accident history to report.

Emergency Response Plan
OXARC, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan in lieu of an Emergency Response Plan due to the few employees on-site during operations. The plan includes all required aspects of the Action Plan and was created using "OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Expert System". The plan identifies alerts, what to do in the event of an emergency, evacuation, extinguishers, operations, employee duties, and meeting points and accountability. Spokane County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee covering this facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
OXARC, Inc. has no plans at the present time.
